Award.AwardTitle: Spectroscopy Predissociation Dynamics and Scattering of Van der Waals Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project supported by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Henning Meyer of the University of Georgia and his students will explore the dynamics of weak intermolecular forces in systems where at least one of the interacting members has an open electronic shell. The research will target complexes of nitric oxide (NO) with various molecular partners like N2, CO, CH4, C2H6 which are important in atmospheric chemistry or with partners like aromatic or hetero aromatic ring molecules which can contribute to the understanding of the biological functionality of NO. Their IR and near-IR vibrational and rotational spectra will be studied through constant photon energy sum (CONPHOENERS) scans, a technique developed in the Meyer laboratory or through action spectroscopy. As a new technique, ionization detected mm-wave absorption spectroscopy will be developed and employed to access transitions in the structural finger print region of the spectrum of these complexes. The experimental data will serve as benchmark to extend or stimulate high level ab initio calculations of interaction potentials towards larger open shell systems including lower symmetry configurations. This is especially important for the extension of dynamics or bound state calculations to include the full inter- and intramolecular coordinate space.

In addition to revealing information about the specific chemical systems targeted in the experimental studies, the research will advance our general understanding of molecular relaxation rates, which in turn are critical to the theoretical modeling of combustion environments or the modeling of chemical reactions in extreme environments not easily amenable to laboratory experiments. Results for the interaction of NO with specific aromatic or hetero-aromatic ring molecules will provide structural information about model sub-units involved in the binding and release of NO in its regulatory function recognized in structural biology. Since the research will involve the development of new spectroscopic tools (based on mm-wave and optical technology) which will bring together very different technical and scientific communities, it will provide unique opportunities for the training of the graduate students supported by this grant. In addition, the Meyer group will invite local high school teachers and undergraduate students (physics, chemistry and science majors) to participate in the proposed research, and thus experience experimental research at the frontiers of chemical physics and physical chemistry

The earth's atmosphere is made up mainly of molecular nitrogen,  N2 (78%),  oxygen, O2 (21%), and the noble gas atom  argon, Ar (1%). It also contains a large number of trace amounts of species like carbon dioxide CO2 (0.04%) and methane CH4 (0.0002%). Although the water  content in the atmosphere is of similar magnitude (0.001%-0.005%), we humans are very sensitive to small differences in humidity. Similarly, extremely small trace amounts of chemically active species in the atmosphere can cause air pollution harmful to human health or crops. While under normal conditions the molecules in our atmosphere are very stable, the addition of energy is required to enable a chemical transformation, i.e. the change from one chemical compound to another. Examples for the energy increase are the increase in temperature (like in a fire or a combustion engine), the absorption of light (red sunset), or the electric breakdown of the atmosphere in lightening during a thunderstorm.

One key ingredient to atmospheric pollution is the compound NOx. It has two important manifestations: nitric oxide (NO) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2).  Under normal atmospheric conditions nitrogen and oxygen in their molecular form (N2 and O2) do not react with each other. In a fossil fuel combustion engine, the temperatures are so high that reactions involving N2 and O2 occur which result in the formation of NO. If NO is not removed from the exhaust, it is oxidized in the atmosphere to form NO2, the other version of NOx. NO2 can absorb light energy causing the molecule to fall apart regenerating NO and releasing an oxygen atom  which combines with normal oxygen (O2) to form ozone O3. Ozone is a powerful oxidizer which can cause skin and eye irritation but also respiratory problems including asthma. Because it affects adversely plant growth, it can have a negative impact on crops. Removal of NOx from conventional combustion engines is still a serious problem as manifested by the recent Volkswagen scandal about the  non-compliance with EPA NOx emission standards for some of its Diesel engines.

In mammals, including humans, NO serves also as an important regulatory molecule which has been implicated in many biological processes including neuro-transmission between nerve cells, and blood pressure regulation. Depending on its concentration, NO can promote cell growth or destruction. These properties could be exploited by  controlling the release of NO in cancer cells causing their programmed death.

Many aspects of the functionality of NO at the microscopic level are still lacking. An important component of the solution can be a detailed theoretical treatment of the interactions of NO with different molecular species forming the microscopic environment for what ever process is of interest. Clearly, any theoretical method must be validated by experimental studies.  In our research, we try to investigate experimentally systems containing  NO and different partners, which can also be treated theoretically. In these experiments, we bring the NO molecule close to its partner under completely isolated conditions in vacuum. We achieve this by expanding  into vacuum a Helium gas mixture which contains trace amounts of NO and the partner of interest. During the expansion, the gas is cooled which causes the partner to attach to the NO molecule. At the same time, the expanding gas forms a rarefied molecular beam in which the complexes are now entrained and isolated.
